The Proper Expenditure
There is presently a trend in college education to
renew stress on the humanities. MIT requires engineering
students to study English and History beyond the elementary level; Princeton's new president is a classics scholar,
and last spring, physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, in a
speech at Goucher College, said "humanities are needed to
give direction to the multiple innovations of modern science."
Last month, Barry Wood, Jr., vice-president of the
Hopkins Hospital, suggested humanities courses be a
required part of the Medical School curriculum, and
President Milton Eisenhower called for more funds to fill
faculty vacancies, especially in the humanities and social
sciences. The need for humanities is being re-established.
Yet at Johns Hopkins, the humanities faculty regrettably will soon lose such scholars as George Boas, Leo
Spitzer, and George Poullet. The problems raised by their
imminent retirement from the faculty are: how to get
other professors adequate to fill their particular vacancies, and how to raise a sufficient amount of money to
attract other outstanding scholars to Hopkins. Basically,
the problems are financial.
The attendant problem of maintaining full ranks in a
superior humanities faculty is that of attracting to the
undergraduate body the best students the nation's high
school system can offer. The present freshman class
draws only 30% of its enrollment from the top ten percent of America's high school classrooms. This statistical
mediocrity can be remedied partially through a strengthened faculty. Assuming a better calibre undergraduate student would be attracted here by an improved faculty, we
also assume that the degree of Hopkins' academic excellence would be raised by the competition to be admitted
to the University and by the subsequently wider range
of superior students from which the admissions office
could select freshmen. Further, both presidents Gilman
and Eisenhower said Hopkins should stand in the forefront of American education—should set the standards.
This goal is impaired by a lack of funds-with which
to form and hold together a faculty of superior research
and teaching ability—a faculty that would attract with
equal drawing power outstanding students to both the
undergraduate and graduate schools.
In light of the recent trend to stress humanities,
even in technical curricula, and in view of the imminent
retirement of several outstanding humanities scholars,
we suggest: improve faculty salaries and thereby the University's degree of academic excellence, especially in the
humanities, and not bother to waste money to send the
lacrosse team to England (it would suffice for the team
to win the National Championship, after 7 years). Consider what will develop the "exceptional man": a superior
teaching and research faculty or a globe-trotting lacrosse

There is presently a trend in college education to
renew stress on the humanities. MIT requires engineering
students to study English and History beyond the elementary level; Princeton's new president is a classics scholar,
and last spring, physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, in a
speech at Goucher College, said "humanities are needed to
give direction to the multiple innovations of modern science."
Last month, Barry Wood, Jr., vice-president of the
Hopkins Hospital, suggested humanities courses be a
required part of the Medical School curriculum, and
President Milton Eisenhower called for more funds to fill
faculty vacancies, especially in the humanities and social
sciences. The need for humanities is being re-established.
Yet at Johns Hopkins, the humanities faculty regrettably will soon lose such scholars as George Boas, Leo
Spitzer, and George Poullet. The problems raised by their
imminent retirement from the faculty are: how to get
other professors adequate to fill their particular vacancies, and how to raise a sufficient amount of money to
attract other outstanding scholars to Hopkins. Basically,
the problems are financial.
The attendant problem of maintaining full ranks in a
superior humanities faculty is that of attracting to the
undergraduate body the best students the nation's high
school system can offer. The present freshman class
draws only 30% of its enrollment from the top ten percent of America's high school classrooms. This statistical
mediocrity can be remedied partially through a strengthened faculty. Assuming a better calibre undergraduate student would be attracted here by an improved faculty, we
also assume that the degree of Hopkins' academic excellence would be raised by the competition to be admitted
to the University and by the subsequently wider range
of superior students from which the admissions office
could select freshmen. Further, both presidents Gilman
and Eisenhower said Hopkins should stand in the forefront of American education—should set the standards.
This goal is impaired by a lack of funds-with which
to form and hold together a faculty of superior research
and teaching ability—a faculty that would attract with
equal drawing power outstanding students to both the
undergraduate and graduate schools.
In light of the recent trend to stress humanities,
even in technical curricula, and in view of the imminent
retirement of several outstanding humanities scholars,
we suggest: improve faculty salaries and thereby the University's degree of academic excellence, especially in the
humanities, and not bother to waste money to send the
lacrosse team to England (it would suffice for the team
to win the National Championship, after 7 years). Consider what will develop the "exceptional man": a superior

Single Wing Background Poses

By AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor
The Baltimore Colts are really
sold on Bridgers," stated John
Steadman, Publicity Director of
the Baltimore Colts. "Coach
Ewbank chose John because he
felt that he was intelligent, and
can get along with people. The
Colts believe that John will be a
fine addition to the staff."
Bridgers, who had been head
football and track coach at Hopkins since 1953, was appointed
to the position of tackle coach of
the pro Colts last Thursday
night. Bridgers, who will begin
full-time work with the Colts
next week, has spent the past
week coaching the Jay trackmen.
This post will now be taken by
George Brown.
Steadman, who joined the
Colt organization after serving
as a sports writer for a local
daily, acknowledged that Ewbank was attracted to Bridgers
after speaking with him at various banquets and at the Colt
training sessions. "The Colt
organization," stated Steadman,"
does not believe that Bridgers
will be hampered by his single
wing background. It will take
only hard work for him to become accustomed to our style of
the 'T'. His basic knowledge of
football should allow him to
make the shift easily."
No Single Wing
When asked if the Colts
planned to shift to the single
wing, Steadman gasped, "No,
definitely not! We will stick to
the 'T'!"
Bridgers believes that the shift
from the single wing will be no
problem at all, because "the
tackle play in pro ball is similar
to the play of a strong side
tackle in the balanced-line single
wing formation."
"The most difficult aspect of
my new job will be the adjustment from coaching college boys
with little or no experience to
the coaching of professionals
who have had from one to twelve
years of pro experience," replied
Bridgers to a News-Letter question.
The new job of the former
Jay coach entails year-round attention. During the off season,

the coaching staff works on the
defenses and offenses of both
the Colts and their opponents.
Movies are used to type team
and individual capabilities. Also,
during this time the play-books
for the coming season are arranged.
New Opportunity
Bridgers stated, "I am looking forward to this new opportunity. I know that I will enjoy
my work, and I hope to learn a
lot more about football. I hate
to leave Hopkins mainly because
of the high standing of the university and the type of boys who
attend the school."

long."

Ramsay High School, where he
lettered in football and baseball.

again lettered in football. Bridgers served in the Army from
1943 to 1946, during which time
he not only rose to the rank of
captain, but also coached football, track, and baseball. After
